Overview. Pulmonary fibrosis means scarring of the lung. Many diseases can cause pulmonary fibrosis including infections, radiation therapy, certain medications, and some diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis, scleroderma, mixed connective tissue disease, and systemic lupus erythematosus. For the form of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis called usual interstitial pneumonitis (the most severe form of pulmonary fibrosis), options can include no treatment, conventional treatment with immunosuppressant medications, and experimental treatment.

Pulmonary fibrosis (literally scarring of the lungs ) is a respiratory disease in which scars are formed in the lung tissues, leading to serious breathing problems. Diseases and conditions that may cause pulmonary fibrosis as a secondary effect include: 1  Inhalation of environmental and occupational pollutants, such as metals in asbestosis, silicosis and exposure to certain gases. 2  Hypersensitivity pneumonitis, most often resulting from inhaling dust contaminated with bacterial, fungal, or animal products. 3  Cigare

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a chronic and ultimately fatal disease characterized by a progressive decline in lung function. The term pulmonary fibrosis means scarring of lung tissue and is the cause of worsening dyspnea (shortness of breath). Fibrosis is usually associated with a poor prognosis. Lung tissue from people with IPF shows a characteristic histopathologic pattern known as usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP). UIP is therefore the pathologic counterpart of IPF. The term ' idiopathic ' is used because the cause of pulmonary fibrosis is still unknown.

In other types of pulmonary fibrosis (such as idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis), there may be little inflammation before scarring develops. The most common symptoms of pulmonary fibrosis are shortness of breath, particularly with activities, and cough. For the form of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis called usual interstitial pneumonitis (the most severe form of pulmonary fibrosis), options can include no treatment, conventional treatment with immunosuppressant medications, and experimental treatment.
